hints_html: Recall that transformations are linear and hence obey the property T(ax)=aT(x) and T(x+y)=T(x)+T(y). Is there anyway that we can represent the vector we want in terms of the vectors we know transformation information for?
hints_latex:
Recall that transformations are linear and hence obey the property
T(ax)=aT(x) and T(x+y)=T(x)+T(y). Is there anyway that we can represent
the vector we want in terms of the vectors we know transformation
information for?
hints_raw: Recall that transformations are linear and hence obey the property T(ax)=aT(x) and T(x+y)=T(x)+T(y).  Is there anyway that we can represent the vector we want in terms of the vectors we know transformation information for?
question: A 20
sols_html:
Notice that I can write [0,1] in terms of the other two vectors [2,3] and [1,1] via,

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 3 \end{bmatrix} -2 \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

Now transformation are linear. This means that T(ax)=aT(x) and T(x+y)=T(x)+T(y). Therefore,

\[\begin{aligned} T\left(\begin{bmatrix}0\\1\end{bmatrix}\right) &= T\left(\begin{bmatrix}2\\3\end{bmatrix}-2\begin{bmatrix}1\\1\end{bmatrix}\right) \\ &=T\left(\begin{bmatrix}2\\3\end{bmatrix}\right)-2T\left(\begin{bmatrix}1\\1\end{bmatrix}\right)\\ &=\begin{bmatrix}1\\2\\8\end{bmatrix}-2\begin{bmatrix}5\\2\\1\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}-9\\-2\\6\end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore

\[\begin{aligned} T\left(\begin{bmatrix}0\\1\end{bmatrix}\right)=\begin{bmatrix}-9\\-2\\6\end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
Notice that I can write [0,1] in terms of the other two vectors [2,3] and [1,1] via,

:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
0\\
1
\end{bmatrix}
=
\begin{bmatrix}
2\\
3
\end{bmatrix}
-2
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
1
\end{bmatrix}.
</math>

Now transformation are linear.  This means that T(ax)=aT(x) and T(x+y)=T(x)+T(y).  Therefore,

:<math>
\begin{align}
T\left(\begin{bmatrix}0\\1\end{bmatrix}\right) &= T\left(\begin{bmatrix}2\\3\end{bmatrix}-2\begin{bmatrix}1\\1\end{bmatrix}\right) \\
&=T\left(\begin{bmatrix}2\\3\end{bmatrix}\right)-2T\left(\begin{bmatrix}1\\1\end{bmatrix}\right)\\
&=\begin{bmatrix}1\\2\\8\end{bmatrix}-2\begin{bmatrix}5\\2\\1\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}-9\\-2\\6\end{bmatrix}.
\end{align}
</math>

Therefore

:<math>
T\left(\begin{bmatrix}0\\1\end{bmatrix}\right)=\begin{bmatrix}-9\\-2\\6\end{bmatrix}.
</math>
statement_html:
Let T be a linear transformation from 2D to 3D such that

\[\begin{aligned} T\left(\left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 1 \end{array}\right]\right) = \left[\begin{array}{c} 5\\ 2 \\ 1 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} T\left(\left[\begin{array}{c} 2 \\ 3 \end{array}\right]\right) = \left[\begin{array}{c} 1\\ 2 \\ 8 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

What is

\[\begin{aligned} T\left(\left[\begin{array}{c} 0 \\ 1 \end{array}\right]\right)?\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
Let ''T'' be a linear transformation from 2D to 3D such that

:<math>
T\left(\left[\begin{array}{c}
1 \\ 1
\end{array}\right]\right) = \left[\begin{array}{c}
5 \\ 2 \\ 1
\end{array}\right]
</math>

and

:<math>
T\left(\left[\begin{array}{c}
2 \\ 3
\end{array}\right]\right) = \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 2 \\ 8
\end{array}\right]
</math>


What is
:<math>
T\left(\left[\begin{array}{c}
0 \\ 1
\end{array}\right]\right)?
</math>
